data.title: Descendents of Don Francisco Sanchez de la Barrera
data.text:
And Dona Maria Duran de Vzcanga

Compiled by John D. Inclan

Return to table of contents

Generation No. 1

1. FRANCISCO2 SANCHEZ-DE-LA-BARRERA (JUAN1 SANCHEZ-Y-ORTEGA) was born 1603 in Lepe, Huelva, Spain, and died February 02, 1677/78 in Monterrey, Nuevo Leon, Mexico. He married MARIA DURAN-DE-VZCANGA Abt. 1625 in Monterrey, Nuevo Leon, Mexico, daughter of ANTONIO DURAN-DE-VZCANGA and CATALINADE TREVINO-AYALA. She was born 1605.

Notes for A

NDRES PRETEL-DE-LOS-COBOS:

A Don Juan Pretel de los Cobos and Dona Maria Leal baptized a Andres Pretel on December 14, 1652 in

Santa Veracruz Catholic Church, Cuauhtemoc, Distrito Federal del Mexico. This may be one and the same?

Notes for M

ARIA-JOSEFADE-LA-GARZA-SOSA:

She is a descendent of the Onate-Zaldivar Family of Zacatecas and colonizers of New Mexico. Another participant in the colonization of New Mexico (USA), and an ancestor of this group is Bernabé de las Casas, who married Dona Beatriz Navarro, the daughter of Don Juan Navarro, a founder of Saltillo. Beatriz was the first wife of Captain Alonso de Sosa Albornoz, killed in New Mexico by orders of Oñate. Alonsos grandfather was the Conquistador Don Andrés de Tapia, perhaps the most trustworthy and reliable of the captains of the Marquis del Valle de Oaxaca, Hernán Cortés.

A History of New Mexico by Gaspar Perez de Villagra, Alcala - 1610, translated by Gilberto Espinosa.

Notes for I

LDEDONSO RAMON-SANCHEZ:

Between 1818 and 1835, he served four terms as Mayor of Laredo.

The following document can be found in the Laredo Archives:

"En la Villa de San Agustin de Laredo del Estado de Tamaulipas, a los diez y siete dias del mes de Julio de mil ochocientos treinta y cuatro, ... , ante mi, Juan Jose Treviño, alcalde constitucional de esta villa, y dos testigos de asistencia con quienes actuo a falta de escrivano Publico, comparecio precente en su propia persona que doy fee consoco, el ciudadano YLDEFONSO RAMON, vecino de esta villa y dijo: que vende en venta real y publica al ciudadano Jose Ygnacio Treviño de Herrera, vecino de Ciudad Guerrero,una porcion de tierra cituada, por de la otra vanda del Rio del lado de abajo, con el numero Cuarenta y Dos (porcion # 42, south side of the river) y que fue adjudicada (granted) a su ABUELO (grandfather) Don MARCOS MENDIOLA, colindante por el lado de arriba."

Notes for J

OSE-SANTIAGO VIDAURRI-VALDEZ:

Jose Santiago VIDAURRI was born on Jul 25 1808 in Lampazos, Nuevo Leon. He died on Jul 8 1867 in Monterrey, Nuevo Leon, Mexico. Jose Santiago Vidaurri was Governor of Nuevo Leon from 1855 to 1864. He fought against the dictatorship of Santa Ana but also became a political enemy of Benito Juarez, who declared him an enemy of the state. He was captured by Porfirio Diaz in Monterrey on the morning of July 8, 1867, and executed by a firing squad on that same day. He was shot in the back, facing away from the firing squad, because he was considered a traitor. His last words were "...let my blood be the last that is spilled and let Mexico be happy". He was first buried in Mexico City; his body was later exhumed and buried in Monterrey and, finally, exhumed again and reburied in the family estate in Lampazos. Parents: Pedro VIDAURRI and Teodora VALDEZ. He was married to Juana Maria VIDAURRI in May 1831.
